segments.text: March 10, 1999, sitting in the living room with Jim Cashion, getting ready to hear his recollections of life at A&M, both when he was growing up, but also as a student.
Your parents came to A&M when?
I believe in August of 1926.
Let's go back and tell me a little about them and their experience before coming here.
Okay, well, my dad graduated from Erskine College in South Carolina and came to Austin College, I'm not sure if it was his first job, about 1912.
I have his, an Austin College ring in 1912.
And he was secretary of the YMCA and at one point athletic director at Austin College until World War I.
And went into the service
I guess under the auspices of the YMCA, I really don't know for sure, but I think it's sort of like the USO was in World War II.
But he was in France with the YMCA during World War I, and after the war he
He joined the British YMCA and was in Egypt and Africa for a little over a year.
My mother was a native of Wills Point, Texas.
And she had friends who lived in Sherman.
And through that connection met my dad just before
World War II, World War I, and they were married in 1925, I believe, 24 or 25, I'm not exactly sure, after he came back to Austin College after the war.
After the war?
After World War I.
Was he again with the YMCA there at Austin College?
That's when he was athletic director.
Did he have any other duties other than that?
I don't think so.
I know he was the general secretary of the YMCA.
As you understand it, in today's terminology, what services did the YMCA provide at that era on a campus?
Well, you're talking about at A&M?
No, at Austin College.
I'm not sure about Austin College.
I'm assuming that it was more or less like the YMCA program at A&M was after he came down here.
All right.
And they come down here in 20...
He came down here in 1925.
He came down as the general secretary of YMCA.
Do you know who it was that hired him?
Do you know any of the circumstances that... No.
You don't remember what his pay was or anything like that?
No.
I remember one time...
Well, this was just before World War II.
And I guess I was probably in high school because I was interested in his buying a new car.
And I went with him one day to pick up his paycheck at the fiscal office.
It was in the new administration building.
And he couldn't find a parking place, and so he just double parked and told me to run in and get his check.
And I did, and I looked at it, and I think it was about maybe $300.
And I thought, oh, my goodness, anybody that's making that much money ought to be able to buy a car.
This was his monthly check.
This was his monthly check.
All right.
So I imagine his salary is $3,500 or so.
I'm not sure.
All right.
He came, and the Y building...
that we know today.
And as far as you know, as far as you can describe what the building contained at the time he got here.
Well, the YMCA building at that time was the nearest thing A&M had to a student center.
They had a semi-basement, but on the main floor there was a big lobby.
They had ping pong tables.
They had easy chairs.
They subscribed to nearly all the major newspapers in the state that the students could read.
They had a desk in the lobby there that the students could buy postcards and stamps and stationery.
And behind the lobby there was a chapel.
and the chapel was used for all sorts of meetings, but the main group that met there, as I recall, was the first president of the church, or the eight emperors that met in the chapel of YMCA.
On Sunday at normal worship hour, I am expressing a bit of surprise that any specific denomination could have used it
Every Sunday?
Every Sunday.
And there was a union Sunday school made up of several denominations that met in the old assembly hall every Sunday morning.
Who taught that?
Was there any legendary teacher?
My dad was taught for a while.
Caroline Mitchell was one of the teachers.
I can't really remember...
And we met under the stage in the assembly hall.
And then later, we met under the stage in Guyon Hall.
There was a space.
You're saying we.
Did you go before you were an A&M student?
Oh, yeah.
By the time I was an A&M student, the Union Sunday School was defunct.
Oh, OK.
Probably in elementary school.
They gave you a pen if you attended for a year.
The second year, you got a wreath around the pen.
And from then on, you got a bar for each year.
I think I had six or eight bars.
The record was held by a guy named Duke Thornton, who is currently a member of South Minister Presbyterian Church in Sugar Land.
And I think he had 14 bars.
Anyway, the YMCA cabinet was made up of students that were interested in the Y program.
As best I can describe, it was the college version of the Hi-Y that was in the high schools.
In the basement of the YMCA, there was, at one time, there was a swimming pool.
And it was not a...
It was there until they built the P.L.
Downs Natatorium.
And can you relate about what year that might have been to you?
I'm guessing it was about 1936.
Okay, so...
But the pool was, it was just a big bathtub.
It didn't have a circuitry system in it.
And once a week, they had...
drain it, scrub the walls, and then refill it.
And that was the only time that I ever got to swim in it.
It had been drained because it was over my head.
And I got to play in it until the water got deep enough that I couldn't stand up and then I had to get out.
So about once a week I got to go swim.
About what dimensions?
The pool was...
Well, it was the size of three bowling alleys.
Because when they built the P.L.
Dow Junior Natatorium, they covered the pool over and put three bowling alleys in the area where the pool had been.
In addition to the bowling alleys, they had pool tables downstairs, there was a barber shop, and Casey's Confectionary, which was a privately run soda fountain.
Could you buy sandwiches and burgers?
Sandwiches and burgers and ice cream.
Let's see.
What that would be normal things today would not have been so.
No beer.
Tobacco?
Yeah, cigarettes.
Tobacco and then just soda fountain types of sandwiches.
I don't think they had hamburgers, but they had
They had sandwiches and ice cream, fountain drinks.
And I'm assuming telephones were there if somebody needed to make a phone call home in that building.
I think there were two or three public telephones in the lobby of the Y.
And to my knowledge, they were the only phones on the campus that the students could use to call home.
And when your dad arrived, the building had already been built, and the Y was a going organization.
Do you remember about the number of staff that he had as a part of the Y?
Well, Jay Gordon Gay was the assistant secretary.
And then the rest of them, he and Gordon were the only two people that
worked on the live program.
The other people that worked in the building, of course, they had the secretary and custodians, but the barbers were, I mean, they were, that was a private barber.
I mean, it was a public barber shop.
And the confectionery was owned by Mr. Sparks and Mr. Casey.
And so, as far as the staff was concerned, it was just,
my dad and Jake Warren Gates.
Describe your dad physically and then describe his personality and what he believed in, good things and things that he wouldn't tolerate.
Well, first of all, he was a Presbyterian elder.
In fact, in those days, it was before the

the sessions that rotated so he was an elder and he was as long as i remember he was an elder on the session of the president one of the things he was concerned about as a as a secretary of the ymca was the fact that uh well in those days the students would come to a m in september
There were no cars, no automobiles.
If they went anywhere, they hitchhiked or they went on the train or the bus, but primarily they hitchhiked.
But for the most part, they stayed on the campus from the time they came in September until probably Thanksgiving.
And then they went home again at Christmas and maybe
if they didn't live too far, at Easter, and then at New Year.

And so they were on the campus for a considerable amount of time, and well, I guess on the weekends they had time on their hands, and he was concerned about the kinds of things that went on in the dormitories, the gambling, and you know, and carousing, and of course there weren't any women around, but he was concerned about
the kinds of things that they had to do on the weekends.
And one of the things that the YMCA did was they sponsored a free show, a free movie.
In fact, the only movies in College Station were run, the movie was in the assembly hall and it was run by the YMCA.
They had movies on Tuesday night and Saturday night for the general public.
the students and anybody else that wanted to go.
On Wednesdays and Fridays, they had what they called, let me see if I can remember the name.
Anyway, they were there to benefit.
The clubs could sponsor a movie and whatever they could make from it.
And on Sunday, the YMCA had a
a movie, they showed a movie starting at one o'clock on Sunday and it was free and everybody wanted to go.
Would those Sunday movies be more serious religion related or would they just be the cheapest thing?
Some of them weren't even talkies, they were silent.
But occasionally they would have one that everybody, but the place was full every Sunday.
They didn't want anything else to do, so everybody went to the movie on Sunday, and then after the movie, they'd play touch football or softball or whatever else they could find to do.
Now, your dad was not part of the rules enforcement staff.
Not that I know of.
Okay.
So his was to be a positive factor.
I guess, you know,
He did an awful lot of counseling, I'm sure, and I don't know what his title might have been, or what level of, you know, he might have been considered as.
He did a lot of counseling with students that were homesick and having problems,
When he came, do you remember his talking about who the key leaders of A&M were in his early years?
Of course, I guess Dr. Walton was the president.
Okay.
No, I don't remember.
Do you remember his ever describing Dr. Walton?
No, except we lived across the street from him, you know.
Oh, so you, oh, all right, well then you describe him.
Well,
Dr. Walton lived in the big house.
Well, first of all, there was the YMCA, and there was a street, and I can't name the name of it, that was right in front of the YMCA, on one corner there.
It intersected with the main entrance from the railroad station.
Military Walk.
No, Military Walk was behind the line.
Oh, oh, oh, that's right, that's right, that's right.
And this was...
It might have been Houston Street.
But at the intersection of the main entrance, the boulevard, from the railroad station to the YMCA, there was the Bugle Stand.
And that street ran, relatively speaking, ran north to the North Gate.
And at the end of the first block, beyond the YMCA,
there was a cross street and on that corner was the President's home.
And it's across the street from what's now the All Faith Chapel.
Beyond the President's home was the hospital.
And Dr. Marsh lived, the college physician lived on the corner there and we lived next door to him.
So we were just
a short block from the president's office.
Now, there were many, many faculty and staff that lived on campus.
Most of them at one time.
As far as you know, was that provided free of charge, or was there a stipend?
I think there was a very small rent charge.
However, I think that probably some faculty members were provided with it.
I don't know which ones.
It never occurred to me to even wonder if my folks ever paid rent.
I know that in about 1939, when they asked us to move off the campus, my dad bought the house that we lived in for less than $500 and had it moved
from the campus down to south of what's now Bush Drive and they set it down there and remodeled it and we lived in it until my dad died and we never sold it.
That was 1939.
What street?
We lived at the corner of Timber and Anna, Homer Covington, I mean Homer,
Homer Adams lives there now.
He bought the house from my mother.
He still lives there.
Back to your dad.
Describe him physically and by personality the way a reporter or a historian might describe him.
Well, he was about 5'10", probably weighed 190.
He had a ruddy complexion and
a high forehead.
He had been an athlete at one time.
He was a pitcher and he had an opportunity to play in the Texas league, but turned it down.
In fact, he played semi-pro baseball and the last game he pitched
was in Oklahoma City, which is not here.
But who is, again, I don't have the slightest idea.
He grew up in South Carolina?
North Carolina.
Where?
At Davidson, North Carolina.
Near Davidson, Huntersville is the name of it.
It was committed right outside of Charlotte.
And his younger brother, Jay, pitched for the Washington Synod.
I ought to tell you who some of the players were, but this was about in the 1920s, I think.
Easygoing?
Easygoing.
He enjoyed the students.
At one time, he probably could call
most of the students by their first name.
All right.
And so your mother and dad come down here.
You said your mom grew up in Texas.
They met at Austin College.
Where did they live when they first got?
Then that house you mentioned?
Right.
They moved it in directly to that house.

They lived in Sherman for a little while before, and I don't know a thing about their deal up there, but they came down here and moved into the house that we lived in until they asked us to move off the campus.
All right, as your memory begins, describe the campus physically.
What buildings were where?
Well, we've talked about the YMCA.
The dormitories that I remember on campus early until they built what's now the core dorms was Walton Hall and there were two small apartment style dormitories that were for graduate students.
One was across from what's now the campus theater across University Drive on the
campus side and the other one was right at the end of Walton Hall that they had to tear down when they built those dorms over there.
Of course there were several houses that faculty members lived in.
Mitchell Hall, Ross Hall, along Military Walk there were, let's see there must have been one, two, three, four, five dorms that I remember, Hart Hall,
I can't think of names on that.
Between Hart, as you go toward the Savisa Hall, there was a dorm right next to Hart Hall, and then Ross Hall that was later the Common Lands Office, and two more dorms.
And then there was the Exchange Store,
B and C unit facility, the building and college utilities that had warehouses and offices and so on.
So there was very little south of Guyon Hall.
There were a few residences south of Guyon Hall.
But no dormitories, no classroom buildings.

south of guyon and or south of the drill field right of course caulfield and the field house were over there and there was nothing but uh fault but the a.m farms west of what's now wilburville that was highway six uh the academic building was there i think the library
And then I believe in 1936 they built the new Texas 6, which is now Texas Avenue.
And when they built it, they had to turn the university around.
And so they built the new administration building.
It was the eastmost building.
I guess it still is.
And you start first grade what year?
I started first grade, well, let's see, it must have been about 1933.
Right, and the school that you attended, what did you all call it?
A.M. Consolidated.
And it was located where?
It was located...
where Dorm 2 is right now.
I don't know what the name of that dorm is, but it's in the core area.
They tore that old school building down when they built the core dorms, and the northwestmost dorm is what we call Dorm 2, and that was almost exactly where the elementary school was.
There was an old
building, Pfeiffer Hall, that was at the south entrance to the academic building that the college loaned or rented or gave to the school district for the high school.
That was where the grades eight through 11 went to school.
About how many were in the first grade?
That'll tell us about how big the enrollment.
Well, I think the grades averaged about 25 to 30.
I know my graduating class after the 11th grade, there were 24 of us.
Oh, really?
Now, what year was that?
That was in 1944.
And everything, all of A&M Consolidated School instruction was on campus until you were a fourth grader or something like that, fourth or fifth, 36 or seven?
We moved off the campus.
I was in the seventh grade.
Seventh grade.
And they built the schools down there off of,
Yeah, what used to be Jersey.
Used to be Jersey Street, right.
And in general, who were the students in this A&M-Saudade school district?
Well, for the most part, they were the children of faculty members.
But they later, I guess there was a school at Peach Creek, and there was a school at Wilburn at one time, and at Milliken.
And at some point,
And I'm not sure exactly when it was.
They combined all those schools, and that's where it consolidated as a thing.
Right.
But when you were in elementary school, those youngsters from out in the country were still going to those country schools.
Well, at some point, I don't remember when they combined us.
But for the most part, I think the ones that I started first grade with graduated.
the ones that didn't quit or something like that.
Because there wasn't much moving around.
People, if they were in the first grade, their parents generally stayed here until they...
So you're born in Brazos County.
Were you born at Old St. Joseph Hospital?
No, I was born in my house on the campus.
Right across from the hospital.
Who was the doctor that came?
Dr. J.E.
Marsh Sr. Jack Marsh Sr.
So the campus physician came...
He was the college doctor, I mean the town doctor.

There were two or three other doctors, Dr. Andre, I remember, and I'm sure there's some others I can't name, but Dr. Marsh was the only one I knew, and we lived across the street from the hospital, and there were
There were two nurses, Mom Clegg Horn and Miss Vaughn, Earline Vaughn, lived in the hospital.
And they were the permanent staff of the hospital.
From time to time, there'd be other nurses if there was a flu epidemic or something.
But Red and I, if we'd get a splinter or for whatever reason,
If we needed his medical attention, we'd go to the hospital, and Mom would take care of us.
One time, we were playing basketball while we were in the Y Chapel.
They had folded chairs, and the chairs were all folded up, and Red and I were in the chapel playing basketball, and I threw the ball to him.
He was standing next to the wall, and it went through his hands and hit him in the head, and knocked his head back against the brick,
and cut a gash in his head.
And of course he was bleeding like everything and it scared us.
So we just went straight to the hospital and put a couple stitches in his head and sent us home.
In fact, Red and I got going to the hospital in the morning, going to the kitchen and the cook was named Collie.
And he would give us something.
He always gave us a glass of grape juice.
And it got so bad that we weren't eating when we got home.
And my mother couldn't figure out what was the matter with us until she found out that we were eating bitter at the hospital before we'd come home.
But not the Marsh.
Our house was between the hospital and the Marsh's house.
He'd walk through our yard, you know, it was just a hundred yards, and he'd walk through our yard.
He always kept bird dogs and horses.
Who were your playmates other than your brother?
Jack Marsh and his sister Louise.
Louise was my age.
Jack was about three years older.
To give you some idea how things were,
One day Jack, I guess we were probably, I was probably fifth or sixth grade, something like that.
Jack says, my dad's going to take out a guy's appendix, you want to watch?
So I said, yeah.
So we went over to the hospital and sat in the window of the operating room while Dr. Marsh took a guy's appendix out.
